data.text: Contents

When a patient is known or thought to be latex allergic the following procedure should be followed: ........................................................................................................................ 10
Theatre guidelines for management of patients sensitive to Latex ............................. 11
Introduction

Natural rubber latex (NRL) is a milky fluid obtained from the Hevea Brasiliensis tree, as with many other natural products, NRL contains proteins to which some individuals may develop an allergy. (HSE website, 2020)

NRL can be found in many products used in health and social care. It has been extensively used in the manufacture of medical gloves because it is very durable and flexible material giving wearers a high degree of dexterity, sensitivity and microbiological protection. It is used in a range of medical devices such as gloves, catheters, anaesthetic masks, ECG electrodes, bandages, anaesthetic equipment and IV administration sets.

The proteins naturally present in NRL can cause the allergies either through direct contact with the skin or by inhalation of powder from powdered latex gloves. The effects of latex allergy can vary from mild irritation to death as a result of anaphylactic shock and that it can affect people of all ages, including children.

It should be noted that the presence of latex as a constituent of a medical device may not always be obvious and care should be taken when treating those with suspected sensitivity. As the frequency and duration of use of latex products has increased (gloves for universal blood and body fluids protection), the emergence of latex sensitisation has been identified for some health care workers and patients, leading to a variety of allergic reactions ranging from urticaria to rare occurrences of anaphylactic shock.
Scope
The Trust has statutory responsibility to protect service users who are allergic to Natural Rubber Latex (NRL).

The purpose of this policy is to ensure that risks to health associated with exposure to NRL protein is assessed and adequate controls are in place for Service Users. To achieve this, the Trust priority objectives are to:
To promote and actively support a consistent approach to the management of those at risk from NRL.
Ensure that staff are aware of their responsibilities for working in such a way that actively embraces those responsibilities.
To work alongside the National Patient Safety Agency on a programme of initiatives to help to ensure that the dangers to latex allergic patients in the NHS are minimised.
Definitions

table_items.text: This terms elates to products that are not manufactured from NRL
Allergic reaction to one or more components of natural latex rubber products.
Control of Substances Hazardous to Health (Regulations, 2002).
Reporting of Injuries, Diseases and Dangerous Occurrences Regulations, 1995.

The process of identifying hazards, who might be affected by such hazards, the risks and consequences of those risks on those identified and controls that can be used to manage or eliminate such risks.
A constituent part of Natural Rubber Latex shown to produce/enhance allergic reactions in susceptible persons.
An immediate hypersensitivity reaction characterised by urticaria, conjunctivitis, rhinitis and occasionally life threatening anaphylaxis.

Characterised by an eczematous rash often developing hours after exposure; it may be due to latex proteins or chemical residues used in latex processing. This reaction predisposes individuals to developing Type I allergy.

data.text: Role & Responsibilities within the Trust
The Health & Safety Committees
The Health & Safety Committees are responsible for monitoring and implementing the policy to review instances of Latex allergy.
Chief Executive
Has ultimate responsibility for the implementation and monitoring of this policy in use  within  the  Trust.  This  responsibility  may  be  delegated  to  an  appropriate colleague.
Chief Nurse
Has delegated responsibility at Executive Board level for risk management and is responsible for ensuring:
There are sufficient resources for the implementation of this Policy.
That this policy is appropriately disseminated throughout the Trust.
The use and management of latex throughout the Trust is both systematic and appropriate.
Clinical Directors and Associate Directors
Provide adequate resources to reduce or control the risk and monitor actions taken to eliminate, control and reduce risks in the area of responsibility.
Trust Purchasing Manager
Is responsible for:
That where reasonably possible, equipment, materials and substances purchased for Trust use are latex free.
That a record of all products which do or do not contain latex within the Trust is maintained.
That all latex gloves purchased are low protein and non-powdered.

When products containing significant amounts of latex are identified that further information is obtained from suppliers, manufacturers, clinicians or the person requiring the product to ascertain its suitability for use in the Trust.
Ensuring that as part of the risk assessment process, managers must only procure products via the Trust procurement systems and where possible utilise latex free products only.

Monitoring all products which have the potential to contain latex by liaising with manufacturers and contract management and to advise those responsible for the purchase of the products of the findings and on the availability of alternative products.
Maintaining a list of latex-free materials to be kept centrally and made accessible to all who need it.
All Trust Managers (Senior Managers, Ward / Departmental Managers)
Managers are responsible for ensuring that the risk associated with NRL allergy to patients is managed in accordance with the Trust Latex Policy and associated protocols and procedures.
Ensuring any NRL allergic reactions of a patient are reported to the Trust via reporting mechanism (Datix Cloud IQ).
Identifying and implementing any actions/or controls required follow NRL Risk Assessment.
Ensuring any adverse reaction to Latex products are fully investigated and reported. RIDDOR 1995.
Ensure that the hypersensitivity is recorded into the Clinical Record via the Medway alert system (code M).
All Clinical Staff
Any patient, particularly those in high-risk groups should be asked specifically about sensitivity to rubber and other known allergies before any non-invasive or invasive procedures are begun.
The facilities to develop a latex-free area to accommodate both allergic and selected high-risk patients should be planned. This is likely to include the
use of a side room that can be made latex-free, specially covered apparatus such as sphygmomanometers, giving sets without latex ports and syringes without latex diaphragms.

Patients for surgery should be first on the list so that the air is as dust free as possible. A latex-free resuscitation set and anaesthetic machine should also be available. The room and patient's bed should clearly be labelled as ‘latex-free'. Latex free gloves should be used in the preparation of the designated area or during any related procedure.
Facilities Estates Services
Must comply with this policy and ensure they use a safer alternative to Latex products when carrying out repairs, maintenance or refurbishments wherever possible.
What is a Latex Allergy?
Latex allergy is an allergic reaction to one or more of the components of natural rubber latex products. There are three recognised types of reactions
Irritation

This is a non-allergic condition, the effects of which are usually reversible. The condition presents itself as a rash, which characteristically is dry and itchy. These symptoms usually resolve once contact with the latex product is discontinued.
Delayed Hypersensitivity (Type IV)

This is known as allergic contact dermatitis, it is characterised by a red itchy scaly rash, often localised to the area of use. The reaction is delayed, occurring several hours after contact, reaching a maximum after 6-48 hours post-exposure and then subsides. Repeated exposure to natural rubber latex may cause the skin condition to extend beyond the area of contact.
Immediate Hypersensitivity (Type I)
This reaction is predominantly a response to the natural protein residue found in natural rubber latex and causes an immediate allergic reaction which is potentially life threatening.

Symptoms are characterised by local or generalised urticaria and oedema. If mucous membranes are affected, rhinitis, conjunctivitis or asthma may result. Respiratory difficulties and anaphylaxis may occur in extreme cases.
Symptoms become progressively more severe on repeated exposure to NRL allergens, so it is important for sensitised individuals to avoid further contact with NRL proteins.
Avoidance of the allergen is the best treatment option.
Modes of exposure
The five ways latex contact can occur are:
Cutaneous - through touch on the skin
Mucosal contact - e.g. from internal examinations, dental treatment, intubation
Inhalation - breathing in micro fine airborne particles e.g. from latex products
Internal tissue - via latex products used during surgery
Intravascular - via injection from products stored or drawn up through rubber bungs on medication vials.
Patients at high risk
Patients exposed to repeated bladder catheterisations
This group is predominantly composed of children suffering from neural tube defects or urogenital malformations.
Patients who have undergone multiple surgical procedures
Patients who are exposed to latex through their occupation
Atopic individuals: People with asthma, hay fever, eczema/dermatitis and certain food allergies (bananas, avocados or kiwi fruit) are strongly associated with the development of allergy to latex.
Symptoms and signs
These include pruritus, erythema, non-urticarial rash, urticaria, angioedema, rhino-conjunctivitis, dyspnoea, asthma/bronchospasm, stridor, hypotension and cardiovascular collapse.

The onset of an allergic reaction may be delayed or insidious (e.g.15-30 minutes) in contrast to drug-induced anaphylaxis, which tend to be immediate in its onset. Consequently, in latex-induced anaphylaxis, the recognition of the nature of the reaction, and its cause, is often delayed.

Staff must be aware of potential dangers of latex allergy, particularly in those individuals with immediate-type hypersensitivity (Type I allergy), who may suffer a reaction on immediate contact with NRL products. All staff should be aware of medical equipment/devices which contain latex, (see appendix 3) and the latex-free alternatives that are available. Such alternatives must be in stock in every clinical area and must not be stored in close proximity to latex products.
Identification and management of patients sensitive to Latex

5.7.1 It is not practical to test every patient with a suspected natural rubber latex (NRL) allergy; Patient displaying relevant allergies should be assessed using the assessment questionnaire Appendix
5.7.2 Each directorate/division is responsible for ensuring staff are aware of items/equipment containing Latex and alternatives items/equipment are available.
5.7.3 Wherever possible products purchased for wards and departments should be NRL-free.
5.7.4 Patients reporting an allergy should complete the full screening questionnaire (Appendix 1) and have their Medway field and Clinical Record labelled appropriately (Medway alert M).
Outpatient clinics and Assessment clinics

5.8.1 This may be the first hospital point of contact for the patient so it is important to identify latex sensitive patients here. All patients attending clinics should be asked about any allergies. If positive responses are given which lead staff to question a latex allergy, the full screening questionnaire should be filled in. (Appendix 1).

5.8.2 All staff should be trained to be aware of the implications of natural rubber latex sensitivity and the need to screen patients. Staff should be aware of risk groups. If a patient is identified as having a latex allergy, then proceed as follows:
Latex allergy sticker should be affixed to the inside front sheet of the patients notes.
Alert all other staff who will be in contact with the patient or who may arrange appropriate investigations
Ensure that only NRL-free products are used and if this is impossible, cover couches with a sheet, and other natural rubber latex items with stockinet. (E.g. BP cuffs and stethoscopes)
5.8.3 Clinics should have dedicated examination trolleys that contain only NRL-free products.
Plaster room

5.9.1 If treating a known NRL-allergic patient and if NRL has been used in the room, the patient should be taken to and treated in a clinic room within the Orthopaedic Out- patients Department. If patients are unknown the staff should ask patients if they have allergies and progress to the NRL allergy screening questionnaire, if appropriate.
5.9.2 Any patient identified as being in a risk group for NRL allergy, should be treated as in the protocol for assessment and outpatient clinics.
Ward Preparation
On admission screening/booking visit, patients will be identified who are known or suspected of being allergic to latex.
The patient, who is known or thought to be allergic to latex, will not come into contact with any latex products wherever possible.
Guidance within this policy on managing the patient will be adhered to.
Latex products will be substituted with non-latex alternatives where available.
Where a latex containing device must be used, every attempt must be made to ensure that the patient does not come into direct contact with latex.
When a patient is known or thought to be latex allergic the
following procedure should be followed:
Accommodation
The patient should be given a single room, with a sign on the door that indicates to anyone entering that the patient has an allergy to latex.
The patient should be given a red allergy bracelet to wear while an inpatient.
Toys given to a child should be non-latex. It might be useful to encourage parents to bring toys in from home.
Staff should wash their hands before they enter the patient's room.
Equipment
No equipment should be used, where possible, on the patient who is known or thought to contain latex.
It is possible to cover latex containing equipment with either non-latex tape, polythene or cotton sheet.
When it is necessary to wear gloves, non-latex gloves should be worn (Vinyl,
PVC or Synthetic late)
Communication
6.3.1  All members of the health care team must be alerted to the fact that the patient is allergic to latex, including physiotherapists and play specialists.
The patient's charts, Electronic Prescription chart (Epma) including medical records and theatre checklist must be completed with allergy to latex.
If the patient needs to attend another department e.g. x-ray, theatres then that department must be notified in advance to ensure that non-latex products are available.

The patient should be first on the list for theatre, outpatients or any department that he/she will be attending If the patient needs to have an anaesthetic, the anaesthetist must be notified at least 24 hours prior to procedure so that appropriate pre-medication may be considered.
Medication
If the patient requires drugs normally distributed in containers with rubber stoppers these should be removed rather than pushing the needle through the stopper.

IV drugs should be administered via a plastic stopcock and NOT the rubber injection ports on the line. Cover up the injection ports to prevent use. Alternatively use an IV line which is known to contain no latex.
Theatre guidelines for management of patients sensitive to Latex
Preoperative management

7.1.1 Theatre staff and the anaesthetist should be given as much prior notification as possible if the patient is known to have a NRL allergy and the allergy must be documented on the Sapphire/Nexus (electronic theatre list).
7.1.2 The Post-Operative Ward staff must also be informed
7.1.3 The Patient must be scheduled first on the am or pm list in order to prepare a safe theatre environment.
Theatre Management

7.2.1 Latex is an aeroallergen and can be present in the air up to an hour after use, therefore where possible the Theatre must not be used for up to one hour prior to operating, and preferably overnight. Traffic flow must be kept to a minimum. Only necessary personnel must be present.
7.2.2 Staff must wear tie up theatre hats only as elastic hats contain Latex.
7.2.3 Warning signs must be visible on Theatre doors. It is essential that each health care worker coming into contact with a patient is aware and a latex free environment is continued at all times.

7.2.4 All items containing latex must be removed from theatre where possible, and be substituted with appropriate latex-free equipment. There is a list of items containing latex available on the Latex Free trolley which is kept updated. A Latex Free Trolley is available containing a range of latex-free products, including anaesthetic equipment, which can be used safely on patients with latex hypersensitivity. Staff must be aware of where the trolley is situated.
7.2.5 Latex-free items must not be stored in close proximity with items containing latex.

7.2.6 Non-latex products must be used for all setting-up procedures prior to surgery. Non- latex surgical gloves and latex free surgical equipment must be used during the entire anaesthetic, surgical and recovery period.
7.2.7 Trolley/table mattresses, supports and seat covers may contain latex and must be covered with a cotton sheet and stockinet.
7.2.8 Tubigrip must not be used as it contains latex.
7.2.9 Anaesthesia should be induced in the operating theatre.
Management of an anaphylactic reaction

Protocols for the management of anaphylactic reactions should be available in every clinical area and should be followed: as with reactions to drugs, the treatment given will depend on the severity of the reaction. If in doubt, senior assistance should be summoned.

The greatest source of latex allergen is the patient's exposure to latex gloves, through the surgical wound or via the mucus membranes. Therefore, the priority to reduce further exposure to latex allergen is for the surgeons, scrub nurse, other theatre staff and all clinical staff to change immediately to latex-free gloves.
Avoidance of Latex
Powdered gloves must not be used at any time
9.1.1 The risk of latex allergy is exacerbated by the use of powdered gloves which increase exposure to latex allergies, not only to the user but to sensitised individuals.

9.1.2 Most powdered gloves have higher extractable protein levels than powder free gloves. When powdered gloves are used in procedures, powder may be introduced into the patient's body or come into contact with mucosal surfaces. This may cause sensitisation and subsequent allergic reaction. Post-operative complications may also occur, such as starch granuloma.
9.1.3 In view of this the Trust through this Policy does not authorise the purchase of powdered gloves.

9.1.4 Staff must switch to powder-free gloves with low extractable protein levels. If this is not effective, wear non-latex gloves. Suitable alternatives in conjunction with the Commodity Advisory Group a latex free glove should be identified.
9.1.5 An equipment database is available in main theatres. The database lists equipment in 3 categories for use in patients with suspected latex allergy:
Training Requirements
No specific training requirements.
Monitoring and Audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Spot check visits by Infection control team

data.text: Approval and Implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Trust's Matrons for local approval. They will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Matrons of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality Impact Assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
References

National  Evidence-Based  Guidelines  for  Preventing  Healthcare  Associated Infections in NHS Hospitals in England. The Journal of Hospital Infection, January, 2014

Appendix 2: Latex Safe Information Leaflet

Are you are allergic to natural rubber latex (NRL)? Contact with this may cause itching, swelling and wheals at the site of contact, and may also cause swelling of the respiratory tract resulting in sneezing and wheezing, and swelling of the conjunctiva resulting in watering eyes.

At present your allergy may not give you many problems, but if you continue to expose yourself to items made from latex you may gradually become more sensitive, so increasing the risk of a more serious reaction. It is therefore advisable to avoid contact with articles containing natural rubber latex as much as possible.
Once sensitised even a short period of contact with natural rubber latex can trigger an allergic reaction. It is most important to take precautions to avoid contact.
The most important items to avoid are latex gloves. People you should inform:

If you visit a doctor, dentist, have blood taken, are scheduled to have a barium enema, etc., you must inform the attending personnel of your allergy and insist you are not examined by anyone wearing latex gloves.
Also inform your hairdresser and beauty therapist. It is advisable to carry some vinyl or nitrile (synthetic) rubber gloves with you to offer to these persons.
If you need a surgical operation only latex free equipment should be used in the operating theatre, as allergic reactions are most likely to occur when the mucous membranes are exposed to latex.
The fact that you are allergic to latex has been recorded on your medical notes at this hospital.
Please ensure that your GP, dentist and any other relevant personnel also record this fact clearly.
Some products that contain natural rubber latex:

This list is not exhaustive. Additional product information may be obtained by contacting the Customer Service Department at the product manufacturers. As a general rule it is thin, flexible items that are most likely to cause problems.
· Balloons and balloon powder
· Tyres
· Adhesive plaster (e.g. Elastoplast) and glues
· Condoms and diaphragm contraceptives. Latex free condoms are available.
· Some stretch textiles – Lycra is latex free
· Knicker elastic
· Cosmetics
· Rubber gloves
· Sports equipment
· Carpeting
· Telephone leads
· Extension cords
· Rubber shoes and boots
· Swimming hats and goggles
· Hot water bottles
· Some shower curtains
· Components of wheelchairs
· Door and window insulation
· Diving masks and equipment
· Suspenders
· Latex mattresses and pillows
· Rubber steering wheel covers
· Bicycle/motorbike handle grips
· Rubber bands and erasers
· Infant dummies
· Many children's toys are made of natural rubber latex
· Chair cushions
NB: Polyvinyl Chloride (PVC), polyurethane (PU) and ethylene vinyl acetate (EVA) can be substituted for products containing latex, e.g. shoes and gloves.
Additional information
It is advisable to wear a Medic-Alert bracelet or locket stating that you are “Allergic to Natural Rubber Latex”.

There appears to be some cross-sensitivity between natural rubber latex and some tropical fruits such as banana, melon, avocado and kiwi fruit as well as potatoes and tomatoes. If necessary, please contact your doctor for further information.
When you are exposed to latex, if your symptoms include wheezing, it may be advisable to carry an adrenaline mini-jet. You should discuss this with your doctor
Visitor / Staff Latex Safe Guidelines
Information for visitors and non-clinical staff Mid & South Essex University Hospitals, about a latex-safe environment.

For the safety of our patients, visitors and staff at our hospital and clinics, we provide a latex-safe environment. This means our buildings are free of latex powder. For this reason, latex balloons are not allowed in Mid & South Essex University Hospitals (MSE), and associated premises.
Why no latex balloons?

Latex balloons contain a powder which helps release them from molds when they are manufactured. This powder carries latex proteins, which can cause some people to have a severe allergic reaction. Latex balloons have an extremely high level of latex proteins, especially when compared to other products made with latex rubber.
When choosing gifts for patients at MSE Hospitals, select gift options other than latex balloons. Foil balloons are a good alternative.
Common questions and answers about latex and why MSE Hospitals are latex safe Q: Why are MSE Hospitals latex safe?

A: The effort to be latex safe helps us provide the highest quality patient care. Being latex safe helps prevent reactions among people who are latex sensitive and the possible development of latex allergy because of continuous exposure to latex products over time. Providing this latex safe environment benefits everyone who enters our buildings.
Q: What are the symptoms of a latex allergic reaction?
A: Reactions can range from mild to life-threatening:
Red and swollen skin, rash, hives or itching,
Itchy, watery eyes, runny nose or sinus irritation,
Coughing or difficulty breathing (wheezing, tightness in chest),
"Anaphylatic shock" - any of the above symptoms plus very low blood pressure and obstructed breathing, leading to heart failure and death if left untreated.
Q: How common is latex allergy?

A: From 1 to 6 percent of the general public and 8 to 17 percent of healthcare workers have a latex allergy. The more often a person is exposed to latex, the greater is his or her chance of developing an allergy.
Those at highest risk for latex allergy are:
People born with spina bifida,
People who have had multiple surgeries,
People exposed to latex at work,
People allergic to bananas, avocados, kiwi and chestnuts
Q: What is MSE doing to reduce exposure to latex?
A: At MSE we:
Have extensively cleaned our buildings to remove latex powder,
Use powder-free latex gloves and supplies for latex-allergic patients and employees,
Do not allow latex celebration balloons in of our facilities, Foil balloons are permitted.
The prevention and management of patients with a latex allergy / MSEPO-21152/1.0
